subject: IpmbSensor:Add bus index for multiple IPMB bus
commitMessage:
IpmbSensor:Add bus index for multiple IPMB bus

IPMB bus is a physical bus which is exposed using IPMB driver. IPMB
is an I2c based serial bus that interconnects the baseboard and
chassis management.

A BMC that includes IPMB interface support and also provides the
capability for system software to send and receive messages to
and from the IPMB using the BMC as a kind of communication
controller.

In OCP multi-host platform, multiple IPMB bus support is present.
Therefore, for each config, IPMB bus value will be passed from
entity-manager json config file.

Through this IPMB bus, BMC will send and receive messages and then
store the response for each configuration.

Example :
        {
            "Address": "0x01",
            "Bus": "$bus",
            "Name": "Temp_Sensor",
            "Type": "IpmbSensor"
        }

In the current patchset, only IPMB bus value is read and further
implementation using this value will be done in the following
patchset.

SDR Sensor :
 https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/52164
 https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/38905

IPMB GPIO State :
 https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/47952

TESTED: Tested on Facebook YosemiteV2 hardware and verified the
IPMB bus value.

Signed-off-by: Jayashree Dhanapal <jayashree-d@hcl.com>
Change-Id: I0a47057da98ee81471ac9f6fac69a036853db7d1

Hi Ed, 

Could you please review this.

Thanks
Do you really want log here? Does not seem needed.

Here, "ipmbBusIndex" variable is set and will be used in other patches based on their requirement. Since, it is not used anywhere in this patch, CI failure occurs. So, I used this log to print that variable to avoid CI failure.
When it is used in the follow up patch, will this log be removed? This probably can just be stdout.
yes, in the follow up patch, it will be removed.

IPMB bus channel is not a well defined term, could refer to one of 4 things, and needs defined in this commit message what you're refering to.

Are you referring to a physical bus number on the BMC?  logical bus number in IPMB?

It is a physical bus which is exposed using IPMB driver.

I will update the commit message.
bus index is not an entity.  Please rephrase this sentence to be more clear.
Ack. I will update the commit message.
Based on this patchset, I see no changes to the "Bus" property, so this statement is confusing to me.

Ack

IPMB Bus Index is used in other 2 patches, so this is a base patch for below patches. In other 2 patches, ipmbBusIndex will be used based on their requirement.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/47952
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/38905

Hi Ed / Zhikui,

Could you please review this patch.

Thanks

Hi Ed / Zhikui,

Could you please provide your suggestion for this patch.

Thanks

Hi Ed,

Could you please provide your suggestion on this patch.

Thanks.
How does that parmeter differ from this one?

IpmbBusIndex is used in /dev/ipmb-x channel to send and receive IPMB commands via ipmbbridge. Whereas HostSMBusIndex is used in /dev/i2c-x and it is used for the machines which are not using ipmb driver.
In general, the i2c index should be enough, and EM should be calling new_device to create an index.  We should not be requiring an abstract bus number that's an internal detail.

In ipmbbridge repo, it is already abstracted and submitted https://github.com/openbmc/ipmbbridge/blob/master/README#L22 . From those information, devIndex is received here. It looks complicated when it is abstracted again here.
@Ed, Could you please provide your suggestions on the above comment.

That's fine, it's quite possible that the maintainer there wasn't aware of those requirements on reactors.  They're free to comment here if they disagree with me, but the fact that they merged an interface that's against one of the core principals of the reactor architecture doesn't change the need here.

Also, I'm super confused at the link you posted.  This commit is about changing IPMBSensor to support multiple channels.  The fact that IPMBBridge (a non-reactor daemon) supports multiple channels already doesn't really change anything about this comment.

In the two indexes, hostSMBusIndex uses i2c and ipmbBusIndex uses ipmbbridge. I'll pass the entity configuration as HostSMBusIndex for ipmb channel in entity-manager and use that variable in IpmbSensor instead of new index.

Currently HostSMBusIndex is used to tell ME which ME's SMBus the target device is on when sending a SendRawPMBusCommand request over IPMB to ME.
It is different than the IPMB bridge bus index.
IPMB bridge index should use a different field name to make it clear.
Done. Used a different name for IPMB index.
@Ed Are you OK with using a separate variable for IPMB Bus Index since HostSMBusIndex is for ME or other Proxy to use?

I guess I"m still not understanding this.  Does the bus exist physically on the board, or is it purley based on the IPMB config file?  This question should be answered in the commit messages of the reviews in question (especially the entity-manager review adding the parameter to a platform), but I don't see it answered, and if I'm confused, that means that it's likely the rest of the community is more confused.

If this is an identification of the remote bus number, lets get it documented that way, add some commit message documentation to that effect, and add something like "remote" to the name, to make it clear that it's not the direct bmc bus number we're talking about.

It is a physical bus which is exposed using IPMB driver. I will submit a patch in entity-manager like HostSMBusIndex and add name as "IPMBBusIndex".

https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/blob/master/schemas/legacy.json#L228

< Does the bus exist physically on the board, 

Clarify on the existing HostSMBusIndex. It is a physical bus that is connected to ME. BMC does not have access directly.

Ah, I misunderstood.  Can we pick a better name for this then?  This has nothing to do with the Host;  Maybe "RemoteBus"?

Also, please make the commit mesage more clear in this regard.
I agree "Host" here is confusing. Unfortunately there might be configuration files out there using this name. How should we maintain compatibility? @Ed

I added a new property type and submitted a new patch in entity-manager(legacy.json) for this IPMB bus index which is named as "RemoteBus".

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/51598

I think we want: 
1. Change HostSMBusIndex to RemoteBusIndex because it is not a bus BMC can access.(My concern is for backwards compatibility with existing config files)

2. Add IpmbBridgeBus for the new index because it is a local bus number BMC is going to use to send the Ipmb command to. 
But, looking at https://github.com/openbmc/ipmbbridge/blob/master/ipmb-channels.json#L5, ("slave-path": "/dev/ipmb-5"), 
I think the "5" is the SMBus number local to BMC, so "Bus" can be used here, without adding a new variable. 

#1 is what @Ed asked earlier

hostSMBusIndex currently using "HostSMBusIndex" to get the bus value. Now "HostSMBusIndex" should be changed to "RemoteBusIndex" in entity-manager(legacy.json) for its compatibility.

For IPMB BusIndex, existing "Bus" can be used to get the bus number.

Could you please confirm this 
@Ed  @Zhikui

Could you please confirm the above comment.
@Ed  @Zhikui

OK from me. 
But as I mentioned this before, change the name (HostSMBusIndex to RemoteBusIndex) is going to break backwards compatibility. Quick search it is used here and probably people's downstream configurations. https://github.com/openbmc/entity-manager/blob/98e102f377d9a5e8f7bbac1063ac39bc5fc8d023/configurations/WFT%20Baseboard.json#L718.

@Ed
Do we have a process to introducing such a change? Maybe allow both for a "grace period"?.

> I agree "Host" here is confusing. Unfortunately there might be configuration files out there using this name.
> How should we maintain compatibility? @Ed

Not quite sure what to do here.....  This might be fine as-is.  Considering that there's no patches that use this parameter yet, I think we've got some time.
Considering this is something that we haven't merged yet, peoples downstreams are free to fix this when the new parameter merges.

There are two "Bus" in discussion here: 
1. HostSMBusIndex, which is already being used, is actually "RemoteBus" for BMC.
https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/master/src/IpmbSensor.cpp#L168
https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/master/src/IpmbSensor.cpp#L531
2. ipmibridge bus index, which is a "local, physical bus" to BMC.
example: both bus-0 and bus-5 are physical buses on BMC in https://github.com/openbmc/ipmbbridge/blob/master/ipmb-channels.json#L11

#1 is not related to the purpose of this patch. I think we can just leave as is.
#2 is at line 472-479: since it is physical bus, use "Bus" seems acceptable.

> There are two "Bus" in discussion here: 
> 1. HostSMBusIndex, which is already being used, is actually "RemoteBus" for BMC.
> https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/master/src/IpmbSensor.cpp#L168
> https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/master/src/IpmbSensor.cpp#L531

That naming is fine.

> 2. ipmibridge bus index, which is a "local, physical bus" to BMC.
> example: both bus-0 and bus-5 are physical buses on BMC in https://github.com/openbmc/ipmbbridge/blob/master/ipmb-channels.json#L11
> 
> #1 is not related to the purpose of this patch. I think we can just leave as is.
> #2 is at line 472-479: since it is physical bus, use "Bus" seems acceptable.

For busses local to the BMC, yes, "Bus" is acceptable and preferred.

Like I said in the other comment, these kind of details need to be in the commit message describing the change.
Done

one thing that confused me originally, is that this keeps calling it the "IPMB channel" when in fact it's the bus of the remote controller.  That needs a lot more detail in your commit message to make that clear.  Also, "Bus" thusfar refers to the local BMC bus that the controller is present on.  LIke we talked about this, needs to be called something like RemoteBus.

Ack.
Could you please confirm the name for ipmbBusIndex. Zhikui Ren suggested that "Bus" seems acceptable for this, since this is a physical bus.

There are two busses in this case:

1. The BMC bus that the device is connected to;  I would like this to be called "Bus"
2. The bus on the remote controller.  It sounds like this is called HostSMBusIndex, which is also fine.  This kind of detail needs to be in your commit message with descriptions of what the parameter does, and what it's intended to control, because this patchset doesn't add an implementation, so it's quite difficult to discern its usage from this patch.
Done
You read this out, but it doesn't get used anywhere?  As written, how does this work?

IPMB Bus Index is used in other 2 patches, so this is a base patch for the below patches. In other 2 patches, ipmbBusIndex will be used based on their requirement.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/47952
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/52164

That's fine, but keep in mind that this patch can't merge until the whole series is do it when you do it this way.  The fact that this parameter isn't used needs to be mentioned in the commit message to convey your intent.
Done

Hi Ed,

Could you please provide your suggestions on this patch.

Thanks
@Ed, Could you please provide your suggestions on this patch.

Patchset as written looks ok, and commit message is now much more clear.

Can't merge this until the patches below it are able to merge, but that's fine, we can start working through those.

Query :
I see ipmbBusIndexDefault is static const with value 0 , wanted to understand advantage of above assignment instead using simply uint8_t ipmbBusIndex = 0;

A constexpr value cannot be modified and it will be executed in the compilation time. Static will define the variable throughout the lifetime of the program, eventhough it is called multiple times, it will allocate memory once, and it is memory efficient.
Looks good to me.
Not needed for success case, please remove

This gerrit patch is a base patch for below 2 features.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/47952
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/52160/20

Since "ipmbBusIndex" variable is not used in this patch, "unused parameter" error occurs in CI, therefore, this log is used here. In the following patchset, it is removed.
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/38905
